description:
Best falafel in the area. I really like the avocado falafel. Reasonable for lunch at $9. Most places have super thick pita bread or over fried/dry falafel. The falafel here is the opposite- thin pita that is sturdy enough to hold all the ingredients, crisp falafel balls that aren't dry, fresh veggies like lettuce, tomatoes, avocado and pickled cabbage. There's also hummus which adds a good creaminess. Ask for some hot sauce if you want a little kick. 

The lentil soup is also pretty good. The small is a big portion if you are eating it there. I would recommend if you want a warm and comforting soup to compliment your wrap (and it's vegan!). This place doesn't get too busy during lunch so if you're in a hurry that's also a plus. We got our food right away and was done with lunch in less than 25 mins.
author: Stine H.

description:
I come here for lunch at least once a week. Their falafel is simply amazing. So fresh and not dry at all. If Oren's hummus combined with their falafel we'd have something special. :) 

People are super nice and I never understood why they aren't more busy. Love this place.
author: Jason P.

description:
Sunrise, IMO, is average for mediterranean food. I've had it twice now; my coworkers really like it and I really was hoping I'd enjoy it more, but it just doesn't do it for me as much as I wanted to. 

Both times I got the lamb gyro and it's been pretty average both times. The pita gets super soggy from all the liquids in the gyro, and doesn't really hold up very well. And I'm not talking about eating it hours later soggy; I'm talking like less than ten minutes. Also the meat is more dry than normal, which makes it harder to eat.

Not dying to go back, but wouldn't mind it either. On the bright side, they have good pickled onions!
author: Jamie J.

description:
For our weekly office lunch, I decided to try Sunrise Deli. (Out of the three spots offered, this was the only one I never tried.) Our delivery order arrived via Caviar on Friday, June 1st a little before 12 noon.

I got the Chicken Kabob Plate: Marinated chicken with lemon, garlic, and Hummus, Tabbouleh Salad, Served with pita bread ($17). The chicken was good. Nicely seasoned and a great smokiness from the char. For the price, I wanted more of my sides. On first look, it looked like a pretty good portion, but then I realized there was only a thin layer of hummus and tabbouleh. It was kind of disappointing as I was still hungry after I ate the whole dish. Even my coworker who thinks all portions are too huge wanted more hummus. And this girl never finishes anything. The sides were okay though. The hummus was creamy and the tabbouleh added a nice freshness.

Decent food, but very skimpy on the portions. If you're a light eater, this might do, but you're probably better off going elsewhere if you wanna get your money's worth.
author: Elena N.

description: I've been taking food from this place dozens of times. Khalid, the cashier at this branch, is aaaaamazingly nice, patient and helpful, the quality of the food is fair but has room for improvement. I would have given this a five star had the quality been as amazing as Khalid and as fast as taking the food from the place.
author: Ali Y.

description:
I am reviewing the falafel in pita pocket sandwich only here. I am a big fan of falafel and have tried most of them in fidi and soma. This one is the best. Falafel is crunchy outside, warm soft and moist inside. Flavor is light and perfect to me. The lettuce, tomato, avocado and other inside the pita are super fresh cut and at all works together how it should. Mmm. Light and healthy lunch choice. The place is run down and needs a remodel but I appreciate their effort making first rate falafel!

Unfortunately most other places cooks the falafel in the morning or the day before and they are served not crunchy, room temp and dry and crumbly inside.
author: Brett K.

description:
Talk about shady.

For $18 the shawarma should at least be edible...so tell me why it was grisly and tasted like it was sitting there for 3 days. Had that unfresh, gross kind of leftover reheated flavor to it.

And it's such a scam how they just spread the hummus ever so lightly on the to go pan so that it barely covers the bottom of the pan.

Is hummus that expensive that you can't provide more than 1/2 millimeter worth?

Overpriced and crappy food. Worst Middle Eastern food I've had in a long time.
author: Jack R.

description:
I'm reviewing this for two separate occasions. The first time I ordered extra meat and they didn't give it, yet still charged me extra. 

The second reason why they get one star is because I ordered them from MealPal and it was the most pathetic meal I've ever ordered using that service. I wish I can give them one star twice, But as far as Mediterranean Food goes this place is pathetic and you have a wayyy better options out there. I was stupid to give you this place second chance.
author: Erik C.

description:
Quick update:
The falafel wrap isn't as huge as it used to be. Nonetheless it's still a pretty decent portion size and most probably wouldn't leave you (or most other people) hungry.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
The chicken shawarma wrap is delicious and is definitely one of the better ones I've had in a while. I think their pickled onions really kicked it up a few notches as it worked really well with the chicken.

I've also had the falafel wrap, and this too is pretty good though not on the same class as the chicken.

Portion sizes for the falafel wrap is more than generous and it would be rare for it to not fill anyone up to their gills; unless you're an active athlete in your 20s. However, the chicken wrap is much smaller and is a medium sized meal.
author: Umesh T.

description: Avocado falafel sandwich was excellent.
author: Sunil R.

description:
Just got the Avocado Falafel through MealPal and was incredibly disappointed due to the demeanor of the employee and rotten food being in my sandwich.

After picking up my food I decided to sit down and have half my pita in the shop. I noticed there was no avocado in the wrap, so I went back to ask them to put it on, which I was then informed it was under the lettuce. After fishing my hand into the pita to move the lettuce around, I found literally one slice of avocado. I asked if I could have a bit more and the guy behind the counter gave me attitude like I was being unreasonable as he put another slice on.

On top of that, when I went to finish the second half of my pita when I got back to work, I noticed that although this half DID have avocado, it was rotten (see pic below). There was a also red cabbage as well that was also dark, dark brown. The avocado and cabbage was so rotten that I don't think you could've made the sandwich without knowing. Obviously this is just speculatuon, but I feel like they were trying to avoid throwing away old food (hence the avocado hiding under a blanket of lettuce).

The falafel and hummus itself was good, but certainly not good enough for me to give this place another try. Miss Tomato right down the street has a better falafel for $2 less.

If the owner wants to get another chance, I'm happy to try it again and revise my review. But I'm certainly not gonna spend $10 to do so.
author: Connor D.

description: The worst falafel I've had ever.... calling it falafel is an insult to falafel. If you want great falafel go to Ayola on Montgomery street or Green olive at Crocker galleria. You don't just deep fry ground chickpeas and call it falafel
author: Madhu J.

description: I just order avocado falafel sandwich thru ritual. It was cold( specially veggies) and did not had avocado in that
author: Krupal B.

description: I ate here on my lunch break and have been shi**ing profusely ever since! I'm actually kinda scared! Like is this even normal? Help me baby Jesus! I just can't go on like this!
author: Tatiana W.

description: Came here for lunch thinking I could grab something quick since there was no line.  My first impression was the place was small and maybe not the cleanest. There were several hairy looking men behind the counter preparing food without any food prep hats or gloves. There was also a lot of food sitting out on tables and counters in questionable looking bins. I ordered a Greek salad with chicken. It cost $16 and there was absolutely nothing special about it. The chicken was small and over salted with no special taste. There was barely any dressing compared to the amount of lettuce. Some bland tomatoes and Greek olives and onion. That was it. Are you kidding me for $16?!!
author: S G.

description:
Wowowwowoowwowo this place was so good!!!! I tried the super falafel and it was amazing! I don't eat a lot of falafels but now I want to try more! The super falafel came in a wrap with eggplant, potatoes, lettuce, tomatoes, and tahini sauce in lavash bread. It was huge! I took my first bite and I was in falafel heaven. They had a super crispy exterior with a soft and flavorful inside. You can tell it was made to order because it was still hot, even after we walked back to the office! The tahini sauce brought the whole wrap together with the vegetables. My favorite was the eggplant, which was very complementary to the falafels!

By the end of the super falafel, I was stuffed. I would come back here for lunch to try more! Some of the items come in pita wraps which look great as well!
author: Tara A.

description: Had a Chicken Shawarma. The taste was good but I have had a scratchy throat for 2 days now :(
author: Gaurav M.

description: I ordered the falafel wrap thru Meal Pal and I didn't really like it, I would not pay full price for it. With the Meal Pal, it's worth a try but I wouldn't be coming back.
author: SuZy Q.

description:
4 STARS FOR THE FALAFEL.

I work over near the TransAmerica building and I still make the trek here even though there's quite a few other Mediterranean places along the way. Yeah, it's about $1-2 dollars more than what I think is reasonable, but their falafels are really the best in the area. That extra dollar or two makes it worth it for me. Perfectly crisp on the outside, savory, soft and slightly crumbly on the inside. Not pasty, dry, or bland like some of the other places. Can't beat a food falafel! 

The service is kinda slow sometimes. They don't go above and beyond but they get the job done. It's not really a place I would sit down and eat.. but the falafels are too damn good to pass up.

SUPER FALAFEL, ALWAYS. The combo of the fried eggplant, falafel and potatoes makes it super hearty and delicious. A comfort food I'll daydream about once every couple of months.

There's also the regular falafel or avocado falafel in the pita pocket but it's too messy. The pickled cabbage makes it a big soggy and it kinda sucks the fresh components of the wrap (lettuce, tomatoes, and cabbage) comes out cold vs cooked components. I agree with all the other recs to get it in the lavash vs. the pita pocket.

Be sure to ask for their hot sauce if you like spicy!
author: Emily C.

description:
This happened to me. I ordered the lamb shawarma and the meat was not warm enough. I asked to have this fixed and they looked at me if I was crazy. Then I mentioned that the meat should be served at a minimum of 140 degrees. The man behind the counter became irritated and said I was condescending. He took my sandwich and placed it on their grill (including lettuce etc.). 

The guy mentioned that he has been doing this for 15 years. The meat was still luke warm. Did not eat it. Buyer beware.
author: Pascal V.

description:
Small Mediterranean place that isn't the fastest place ever either. Had to wait around 10 minutes even though there weren't many people in front of me. Probably like 5 people.

I got the chicken shawarma which comes with Marinated Chicken Breast with Lemon and Garlic, with Hummus, Lettuce, Tomatoes, Tahini Sauce, served in a pita bread. 

First of all, the portions were really small and it was like super thin. Compared to my coworkers who both got felafels which were bigger and seemed more filling made me question this place. Also it was $10 so the value really wasn't there for me. 

The chicken was dry and the tahini sauce was very sour which I didn't like at all. I was expecting more of a savoury and saltier taste rather than this sour pickly flavoured shawarma. I wouldn't come back.

Also the service people were kind of rude because I thought they gave my meal to my coworker but I messed up and admitted I was wrong but they made a big deal about it for no reason...
author: Christopher L.

description: The workers are super lfriendly, and got my falafel plate in less than a minute! Checking in and writing this review took more time!
author: Jeffrey D.

description: I had m 2 disappointing meals from this place. Never going back here again. And the food is always slow even though i haven't seen any crowd there, not sure why it's taking so long to prepare bad sandwiches. I felt the food is never fresh here. Will never come back here !
author: Shwetz M.

description: Got the lamb shwarma. Completely underwhelming - way too many onions and hardly any lamb, and the lamb that was there was hard and overcooked. I will not be returning.
author: Asha R.

description: No line. Cashier took my order immediately. Very friendly service and food was ready within 2 minutes (not exaggerating)! A little over priced at 9$ for a chicken shawarma. The reason why I didn't give this place a 5 was because the food was average. I have had better. I would go back if there wasn't a restaurant for chicken shawarmas closer.
author: Lauren C.

description: BEWARE!! Worst customer service ! The girl who works here is very rude . Place is very unclean and food sucks
author: Neeva J.

description: Wow...I guess I'm used to Truly Mediterranean where the super falafel sandwich is big and bursting with fillings and flavor. This was small, salty, bland, uninspired and overpriced. Couldn't find the eggplant. Probably three falafel balls and some lettuce. No cucumber/tomato mix. The lavash was rolled about four times so the sandwich was mostly bread. Nothing super about it. Pathetic.
author: B. L.

description:
great kofta kebab sammich.  Looks like a small sammich, but it was heavy after all was down and done. 

Does not support apple pay however. I could not figure out how to touch the (dirty) machine.
author: Jordan G.

description: I ordered the super falafel sandwich. The falafel in the sandwich were not very hot or crispy. There was a lot of wrap and not enough falafel. There was a disproportional amount of lettuce. The wrap overall was relatively dry.
author: James S.

description:
First let me say that the Falafels are 5 Star.  They are delicious just by themselves, and you can order 6 ($5) or 12 ($8) in a paper bag to go.  They are freshly cooked.  While the inside tastes pretty typical of a good falafel, it's the outside that is unique.  They have a great crunch, and I think they pick up a nice flavor from the oil they are cooked in.

I ordered the Avocado Falafel in a Pita for $9.  It's served in a thin, cold pita, that can easily break open.  Other than the Falafel, the flavors of the other ingredients are just OK.  If I remember right, you get a total of 4 falafel as the pita is rather small.

In a perfect world, I would order some Falafel from Sunrise Deli, run a few blocks and ask Sabra Grill https://www.yelp.com/biz/sabra-grill-san-francisco to use those Falafel in their warm thick pita with all the trimmings.  That would taste great.

I also tried a half pint of their Mujaddara (Rice and Lentils) for $5.  Though I really like most Mujaddaras, this was one of the worst.  The rice was overcooked and soft, and had a yellow color.  The lentils were OK, and there was little to no onion.  It basically tasted like something that had been made a few days before and reheated.  Other than bulk, the Mujaddara added nothing to my meal, and I wish I had not ordered it.

So, on the strength of the Falafels, I'll give an overall rating of 3 stars.

_______________
On another visit, I tried a small Lentil Soup for $5, and a Lamb Shawarma for $9.

I really liked the lentil soup.  While a bit too salty for me, it had nice flavor.

The flavor of the Lamb in the Shawarma was OK; but, overall the Lamb was dry and the shawarma needed more flavor.  I tried adding hot sauce.  Believe it or not, spooning the lentil soup into the Shawarma made it more moist and really added a nice flavor.
author: Roy C.

description: Don't get me wrong! I love the falafels in this place and I am usually getting their super falafel wraps to go! For some reason, the tall dude with mustache who takes orders need to get off his phone! He is constantly on his phone even when he is taking orders and sitting in the back. On two separate occasions, I ordered two super falafel wraps and neither one had the eggplant nor potatoes in it. Today, I did the same and I said I wanted some hot sauce on the side. I was served regular falafels again and no hot sauce in the bag. Oh he will hold the tipping screen on your face when he is swiping your card, mind you! Can't believe how it takes so much rocket science to put in the right order and drop some hot sauce in a paper bag!
author: Emre T.

description:
This is a great casual spot for a weekday lunch. They have plenty of options for vegetarians and met-eaters. 

Their falafels are so soft, yummy and out of this world!

Avocado Falafel - This is a good one but a really messy sandwich. It's open and come in a pita pocket. If you don't want it messy, ask them in a lavish wrap

Super Falafel - I love this one. It's not as messy because it comes in a wrap. Recommend it!

You can ask them to make any sandwich spicy.
author: Hiral P.

description:
I need to rectify the bad reviews on here.
NEED TO.

Ok, Ok, so I'm sure everything everyone said is valid and I'm only speaking from a catering standpoint (i ordered through EZ Cater), BUT OH MY LORD IT'S GOOD.

SO GOOD.
Best Falafel of my lifetime.
Meat platter so flavorful. 
I got major kudos for ordering from them, and will continue to do so. It's insanely good.

So maybe they are hit and miss, but when they hit - OMG SO INSANELY GOOD.
author: Jane H.

description:
I came in here with co-workers, at their suggestion.  They said it's got great falafel.  Of course, being the independent thinker that I am, I went with the chicken shawarma--big mistake.  While my co-workers scarfed down a meal that they've clearly enjoyed a million times, I was forced to nibble on one of the most bland shawarmas I have ever eaten.  There was no spice and absolutely no flavor.  The bread was OK, the chicken was luke warm (if not cold) and, I cannot say it enough--IT HAD NO FLAVOR!!! What the f@*$ did I just eat? I was so hungry, too.  What a disappointment.  Time to start thinking about what to eat for dinner, so I can make up for this dud.

I can't speak to the falafel, since I didn't eat it.  Though, I cannot recommend this place.  If I come back (am dragged back here) with co-workers, I will try the falafel and pray for a better experience.
author: Pablo O.

description:
I found their truck at Oaktown's First Fridays, which was labeled "Established 1984", so I thought this must be legit. The lamb schwarma was a huge disappointment. The meat was this weird almost black color and dry. Wtf! But, I was starving especially after waiting 25 min to get it. The whole thing was barely lukewarm, and the wrap could've been heated up to soften it up some. Overall, the schwarma was small, skimpy on the meat (maybe a good thing), bland and dry. 

I might give them another chance for their falafels after reading good things about it here.
author: Elly L.

description: i wanted to order a chicken kabob but the employee working there told me i would have to wait 8-10 minutes so i decided to order the chicken shawarma plate. because it came in a big bowl, i thought the portion size was relevantly big. it was pretty deceiving because once i took off the lid, there wasn't much in my bowl and i paid $15 for it :( the appearance of the food looked nice but the overall, the food was okay. i mainly ate the chicken and dipped my pita bread in the hummus. i wouldn't come back here to eat again. i can definitely get cheaper, bigger portion, and better tasting shawarma elsewhere.
author: Sylvia H.

description: Went there for a late lunch. The shawarma was cold. It's not like they were busy and didn't have time to heat it up. They take no pride in their food. Give this place a miss.
author: Ruairi G.

description: Ordered a chicken schwarma and was surprised how fast it came out. It was half cold like it came out of the fridge and was partially heated. It was obviously made too fast to have been freshly made. While the meat was marinated and flavorful, it was quite a disappointment.
author: Steven A.

description:
Their tabouli salad and falafels are addicting. I've also tried their wraps and its a big portion! Lunch will run you around $10-12 here.
Fast service and right near my office.

FYI- They have a PayPal deal for $5 off your purchase.
author: Angela D.

description: Haven't been here in a while. Got the chicken shawarma plate and the quality has gone way down and the prices way up.
author: robin b.

description: Got the lamb Schwarma plate. Total waste of money. $15 for maybe a $6 portion. Go to oasis grill. Way better.
author: Kevin A.

description:
I smell a turf war a-coming on 2nd Street now that Gyro King has opened on the same block as Sunset Deli. Forget Iran. This is where the real Middle Eastern conflict is taking place... The Jets are gonna have their day. Tonight. The Sharks are gonna have their way. Tonight. Anita's gonna get her kicks. Tonight. We'll have our private little mix. Tonight. Tonight, tonight, won't be just any night. Tonight there will be no morning star....but enough "West Side Story" (fingers continue to snap in unison)...Enough already! So until the rumble, Sunset Deli has the upper hand by having been there for a while serving up some pretty tasty falafels, shawarmas, and shish kebabs through the lunch rush.

But they have two strikes against them. They're a bit pricey, and seating can be a chore to find if you plan to eat it there. Tables pack up fast around noon, which has definitely discouraged me from coming here more often. I came around 1:30PM last week, and the queue was still quite long. Regardless, I managed to secure a small table in front when I got my food. And what did I order you ask? The special of the day as a matter of fact, the $8.99 Moussaka, huge slices of eggplants topped with ground lamb and a heavy ladleful of fresh tomato sauce. It came with rice and a side salad of cucumbers, tomatoes and red onions (see photo). There was a basket with a couple of pita halves to scoop up some of it. Good, hearty eats, but a dollar or two more than it had to be. Alas, the rumble may settle the score. Tonight.

FOOD - 3.5 stars...good, hearty Mediterranean fare...loosen your belt buckle and the grip you have on your wallet
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...let's get small, shall we?
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...I just remember someone yelling at me by my dish
TOTAL - 3 stars...sunrise, sunset...is this the little kebab I carried?
author: Ed U.

description:
One of the many Mediterranean restaurants in the area. I always order their Super Falafel as their falafel are the best. They are crispy, oil-less and delicious.

The quantity of food is enough for lunch. Priced at par to other middle eastern restaurants in the area.

I took a star off as sometimes there's a wait for placing an order because the cashier moves to making the order instead of placing it. Maybe they run the place with low staff.
author: Jay M.

description:
I'm always wary when businesses feel the need to toot their own horn...and Sunrise surely does that from their sign for serving the "best" middle eastern food since 1984.  I always pass by this location but never had the urge to try it at least once, and thanks to the PayPal deal, I came here on a whim to at least give it a chance.

Now, I'm no expert in middle eastern cuisine, but the most appealing item to me was the lamb gyro.  The wait was relatively short, give or take 5 minutes and off I went.  When you open the wrap, it looked soooo doggone appetizing, I was in for a treat!  That is...until the first few bites.  The lamb was overcooked, bland (even though they added a bunch of spices), and just tasted...well, plain.  The portion was huge but it just did not appeal to my palette.  Maybe it's because middle eastern food  is supposed to taste bland?  

I don't know, but this place was unfortunately a miss in my book.  The prices are reasonable in comparison to the other options around FiDi, but I won't be scurrying back here anytime soon.
author: Kevin C.

description:
I ordered the Beef/Lamb Shawarma Plate and for $13, it's not worth it at all.  

Meat that's been pre-prepared and sitting out waiting to serve is not the way to earn repeat business.  Always make the meat to order so it's hot and fresh.  My dish was ALL cold.  

There's many other destinations that care more about the way they serve food and still give you a better value.

I don't even think if the cost was cheaper I'd eat here again.

Find it and forget it.

J
author: John M.

description: I got the Lamb Shwarma pita and it was small, overpriced and just not very good. The lamb has this weird gritty texture like its been boiled and the meat just sat in the boiling liquid. I will not go back.
author: Charles W.

description:
I've been to their Irving location (falafels are awesome!)  So I opted to try their daily special which was moussake.  

Moussaka, interesting presentation.  It's a huge slice of cooked eggplant, with the meat sauce on top.  It's delicious but I have never had moussaka presented that way.  The rice that came with it was delicious too.

Prices = reasonable.  A person can escape with paying $10.00 for a meal here.

Service = order at the counter, and the rest, you're on your own (silverware, securing a table, water, etc.)

Overall, I'd order take-out from here and save myself the hassle of sitting at their tables.
author: Fannie S.

description:
Best falafels in town? Hmmm.... I'll have to double check that. I'm pretty partial to the falafels at Truly Mediterranean but I didn't do a true test. I only ordered the super falafel sandwich (With Hummus, Eggplant, Potatoes, Lettuce, Tomatoes, Tahini Sauce, served in lavish bread) which was admittedly very good. A lot of falafel are too hard, dry and crumbly but these are exactly how they should be - basically the complete opposite, tender balls, moist and delish.

But to really test the falafel I'll have to get some by themselves. I know, I know, the sacrifices I'll have to make to come back to eat their really good falafel and compare to another really good falafel. 

I think the falafels can be ordered by themselves for 50¢ each (approx) which is slightly more expensive than Truly Mediterranean (I can usually get a bakers dozen for handful of dollars).
author: Jean K.

description: This place is the read deal.  BEST falafel I've had in the city, hands down.  I will definitely be back!
author: Brooke M.

description:
Agreed by all: Best. Falafel. Ever.

I didn't believe my friend when she told me Sunrise Deli has the best falafels she's ever eaten. Sure I like falafels. But what could really make falafels so awesome? Well that was my own ignorance - these falafels had an incredibly thick and rich breading on the outside. Amazing crunch, countering the dense, smooth, and flavorful filling. Wow.

The rest of the food was good. Not quite as amazing as the falafel, but solid. I think if I'd ONLY gotten the falafel, it would've been 5 stars =).

* Shawarma Plate (Lamb Shawarma served in a Ring of Hummus with Onions, Tomatoes, and Tahini Sauce, served with pita bread) - Pita bread was medium thick and a good side. The lamb quality was pretty good, fairly tender, and overall dish was fairly enjoyable. I would just say the tahini sauce could have used a little more flavor/ seasoning.

* Kabob Plate (Chicken Kabob served with two side orders (babaganoush & falafels), served with pita bread) - Gotta reiterate - the falafels were the highlight. Babaganoush was a little too homogeneous (over-pureed). I like having more texture from the eggplant. But the chicken was pretty amazing, really nice & moist & tender.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
I hate for my 300th review to be a one star, but I can't help it. I have to say something about this particular Sunrise Deli.

The worst lamb shawarma I've ever had...ever!

The lamb was marinated in some weird salty mix and was so dry and a weird texture. I hated it! To make matters worse, the portion of veggies to meat in the shawarma itself were very disproportional - there were several bites in a row of only lamb with no veggies and several bites in a row of only veggies with no lamb (which I actually didn't mind because the lamb was disgusting!). The shawarma was put together very haphazardly and fell apart in the middle. I waited 15 minutes for this, 15 minutes!

I will never return to this Sunrise Deli and that's why it deserves a one star in my books.
author: Junel S.

description: Stale pita bread. Cold rice. Raw chicken. Nothing redeeming about this place. I would vote this the worst of the worst, but JUHU Beach Club served up the same kind of food except charged an arm and a soggy chicken leg.
author: S. G.

description:
Very disappointing meal which cost 12$. 

I ordered the lamb plate thinking it would come with a side of salad, a side of hummus, & some pita bread (the usual). When I opened my (already decomposing) to-go box I realized that the lamb was basically thrown into a pile of hummus (which was quite good & rich) and there was no salad to be seen...

The main disappointment was the lamb - it was chewy. 

Yes, FiDi is expensive, but there are still far superior options 12 bucks will buy.
author: Nina M.

description:
$13 for three "pucks" called kabobs, that in my 3 minute walk back to my office were cold when I got there. I mean literally its a puck of meat, Absolutely disgusting, with so many options in SF trust me, pass this one up and go anywhere else...I do mean anywhere. 

Don't get me started with the pita...if you can call it a pita. Dry, crusty and barely edible. 

Whomever thinks they have the "best" middle eastern food clearly is confused...
author: Malbec S.

description:
I hate writing bad reviews, especially when they do have good customer service (hence the additional star).

I got the lamb schwarma and it's just so bad.

The lamb is dry and chewy, I had to spit some out. The pita is cold and tastes like it's from a bag.

Maybe I came too late (after lunch rush) and I got the bad leftovers but unfortunately that's enough to make me not want to return :(

Waste of $9.
author: Jordan S.

description:
I've been here several times, so maybe my rating is tainted by the varied experiences I've had here. It's not a bad spot for lunch. You can't beat the location...it's directly across from my work!

 I agree wth some reviewers that it's a bit pricey. I once asked if I could get a half order, since their servings are huge and they said no. I end up throwing half my chicken shawerma plate out most of the time.

Their falafel plate is very good. I love their hummus. 

I wish they carried bottled or canned diet coke. They only have found drinks or snapple. 

The wait for your order is quite long... I grow impatient, as I am usually running out during my lunch hour, which is really a lunch " minute."
author: Bernadette W.

description: The food was served cold. I ordered chicken sharwarma and my friend ordered kabob both were cold. No taste.chicken was not freashly cooked. If u r a sharwarma lover dnt go here ever. Owner n workers were rude as hell. And no garlic sauce at a middle estern restaurant is unheard of. Worst experience ever.
author: Faisal Y.

description:
Really tasty, although a bit over-priced.

I ordered the Veggie Combo plate, which was really delicious.  The falafel is definitely the star.  It's so fresh and tasty, nice and crispy so it doesn't just fall apart when you break off a small piece.  My other favorite part of the plate is the rice and lentils topped with fried onion strings.  So much of the plate is veggie items that are by nature very sour, that the fried food really pops and is a perfect compliment.  The hummus was decent, but nothing special, and I thought the pita bread was a little thin.  

I would've given this 4 stars for flavor, but knocking off a star because it's overpriced.  This would be my go-to falafel place if it weren't for the price.
author: Dave S.

description: Falafels are the best in the bay - seriously, crunchy on the outside, moist on the inside. Total dynamite!
author: Taryn E.

description:
Perhaps the worst service I have ever received in San Francisco. Granted this is a deli and not a renowned restaurant my expectation isn't world class service however it is fair to assume that any business wishing to do well will at least have a staff which is respectful and doesn't outlash on their clientele.


Unfortunately for one reason or another, when I tried to pay via paypal, I didn't populate into their system. As a result, I made an order to go via eat24.com so I can pay with my mobile device and despite showing my receipt of a completed transaction I waited 10 minutes for the transaction to be processed in their archaic fax order system. 

The transaction was delayed and the staff insisted that I continue to wait after the 10 minutes even though I had a receipt on my phone with a system that they use frequently. 

I had relayed my frustrations and the man behind the counter who was dressed as he had just come from a snoop dog concert with ungroomed facial hair (which ended up in my colleagues food) lashed out at me "wait like everyone else"! The fact was no one was in a similar situation or had waited. 

It doesn't take a brain scientist to have the logic to make an approval which is low risk to keep a frequent client happy. If you don't have the skills to make such an assessment, kindly say "unfortunately this is the only way we can do it". 

If you fancy poor service and hair in your food, I would highly recommend Sunrise Deli on 2nd street.
author: Parul G.

description:
I know Sunrise deli has tasty food, and if you go when it's busy then you'll have a good time I'm sure. 

I tried to go here today, around 3:30 - 3:50 and saw the sign said Open, so I walked in to find out it was really closed. Just like their location in the outer sunset, they tend to close early, so you can't really expect them to be open which is a bummer.
author: Albert F.

description:
Um... that falafel is not the best falafel in the city. Not even close.


Alright maybe it is if you live in the same world where Tony's has the best pizza in the world. Then sure, knock yourself out.
author: Emily D.

description:
Chicken Kabob wrap was partially frozen, painted yellow, pink in some areas, dry and bland. Pita was stale. No flavor at all. Won't be back.

Plus, I felt a little nauseous after. Might not have been related, but I'm suspecting it was.
author: Big D.

description: Their hummus is extremely bland (no tahini?) and only one piece of dolma comes on the veggie plate.
author: Rachel G.

description:
I use to love coming here to get the chicken kabob plate. Healthy, gluten-free lunch option in FiDi. I love their babaghanouj.

Sadly they recently increased their prices and now that plate is almost $14. Completely overpriced for what amounts to a few pieces of chicken, a dip and a tabouli salad. I cannot justify the cost to go here anymore when there are so many other lunch options in the area.  

I've also noticed that the line isn't as long here anymore. Guess people figured it out.
author: Tomy T.

description:
Okay the problem with falafel is how most people make it then let it sit around all day. Maybe not all day but the thing is it needs to be eaten within a few minutes after comes out of the oil. This place was disappointing when I went in for an early lunch at 11 AM on Friday. The falafel was dry it was cold and it was not yummy.

The pickles tasted like they were dipped in some weird chemical.

But the saving grace was the baba ghanouj. It was very good and I got some to take home.

An acquaintance from Israel told me that this place was the best in town. I don't think so  -- sorry.
author: ari s.

description:
Went here for lunch last week--look, I would not waste my time at this place UNLESS you get onto the Groupon deal and get two platters for the price of one. You are paying only about $6 for a platter, which is just about fair for what you get.

I'm a huge advocate of paying for what you get. Here the food is not up to par with what the price demands.
author: Chrissy H.

description:
Seems there's a lot of haters here. I went to the food truck on Mission between Fremont and 1st. I'm not sure if this is the same place but a search for the food truck only turned up one in the Avenues. Perusing the menus I can see this is the same deal and I know it must be run by the same people, so here goes.
Fortunately I found the food truck towards the end of lunch. The crowd had disappeared. For some reason though, even though there was only one guy waiting for his food, we both waited for at least 20 minutes for our food. A true WTF moment.
After I got my food (standard chicken plate with hummus and cucumber salad) I walked off to sit down, only to discover they forgot to include my falafels. I walked back and fortunately one of the staffers was in a jovial mood and wanted to give me more than I ordered, possibly because they were done for the day and closing. So, he gave me 6 falafels, 3 more than I paid for, along with an extra side of hummus. Bonus.
The food was, I have to say, excellent. It was definitely of food truck calibre, I thought. The hummus was too watery but it had a good creaminess and was not overly garlicky. The falafel was, as others have stated, the best. Crunchy non oily goodness. Slathered with hummus it is divine.
The chicken was very tasty. Not necessarily best I've had but not bad at all. The cucumber and tomato salad was fresh and satisfying. 
All in all if I didn't have the annoying wait and forgotten falafels this might be a 5 star deal.
author: Matt H.

description:
Now that I work a couple blocks from this location, there's rarely a day that goes by without me contemplating getting falafel for lunch. And with the cheap the prices, why not?

I almost always go for the super falafel. As much as I love avocado (and pita), the super falafel is really what I need to satisfy my craving. Falafel, potatoes, eggplant, hummus, tahini...simply delectable.

I'm also fond of getting the cucumber and tomato salad. For a couple dollars you get a half pint of small persian cucumbers sliced up with wedges of tomato, a little bit of onion, and lots of parsley and vinaigrette sauce.

Only a couple grievances about Sunrise. First, they're not open past 5pm. I mean, yea, it's probably better that I don't have their open doors taunting me every day after work on my walk back to Muni, but still, the option would be nice. Second, and this is much more important, they stock pepsi products in the soda fountains. As everyone in the know knows, this is a crime against taste, if not against mankind in general.

Watch for deals on groupon, google deals (maybe yelp too?)
author: Jon T.

description:
The falafel was actually pretty good. It was, however, not hot and falafel is always better hot and cooked on the spot. 
There were two people working. One who took my order and got my order ready and then there was a woman standing at the counter doing her bills, where the food is prepped. This was at 12:30 during the lunch hour. She had all this paper work spread everywhere. A huge turnoff when that is also where my food is being prepared.
author: Adrienne G.

description:
Hell. Yes.  They live up to their motto "Best Falafels in town!"  I remember eating at their location on Irving years and years ago and since then kind of forgot about them.  Well, I needed to order lunch for my office and though Middle Eastern food would be a good and healthy choice.  I came across these guys again and remembered how I loved the one on Irving. 

I ordered everything the day before using Eat 24.  They don't deliver to my area so I opted to get a task rabbit to pick it up.

Everything was done on time as requested and the portions were perfect.  I went with a large veggie platter and a large meat platter.  I paid about 200 bucks and it fed 12 big eaters.  In fact, a few people went in for seconds.  

The hummus was so velvety and smooth.  The dolmas were a great consistency, the meats were all flavorful and tender and the falafels were AMAZING.  

My only grip... I wish I had more hummus.  That was the first thing to go.

Love love love this place.  I'll remember them the next time I do another office order.
author: Jennifer C.

description: literally the best falafel in town. i typically get avocado falafel and add feta. it's a bit $$ but COMPLETELY worth it. i've been coming here for maybe four years now and have never had awful falafel like at other places. it's always full of flavor and i'm salivating just trying to find the words to describe it. never dry, never bland, always perfectly seasoned and cooked. thank u for existing, sunrise.
author: Yves D.

description: I ate from their truck and it was awful. I had the chicken shawarma and it was edible because I was starving but still couldn't finish it and would never eat it again. We also got the chicken kabob plate - hummus gross, rice and lentil undercooked, and the chicken just not tasty. I will never eat there again. Ended up throwing away an uneaten plate.
author: Ericka S.

description: Just what I wanted: a lukewarm, dry, utterly bland, aggressively pita'd chicken shawarma for lunch.  Oh wait, my trash can wanted it more.  Sunrise deli sucks.
author: Pamela J.

description:
Ah, falafels. 

Sunrise Deli does a pretty solid job on your basic falafel. For $5.99 (= tax comes to a tidy $6.50, gives two laundry chips in change). I am spoiled by Mamoun's but what are you gonna do. This ain't Kansas. And by Kansas I mean NYC.

It's a bit cramped inside but head straight to the cash register in the back left. They're not the fastest at lunch, even with 4 guys in the kitchen but that's ok. Be patient and keep an eye on your number. Because when they call out "regular falafel!" and someone grabs it, don't be upset- that's regular falafel order # 87 while you have #99. 

Sandwich construction? Lettuce, diced tomatoes and fresh, not overly crispy falafel balls. My favorite part? They provide the sandwich in two parts. Helps with portion control and allows you to save the other half for dinner. Double your daily dose. Yum!  

Ask for the hot sauce too. It's more of a thin liquid than sauce but does a nice dance on your tongue. Won't burn it off.
author: Kim K.

description:
I don't know what the past reviews experienced, but I've been coming here and the other locations for years and it is most definitely the best falafel in the bay! The shawerma is also really good.

They also just opened a food truck that I stalk on twitter and grab lunch from whenever I can. 

Try Sunrise, you won't regret it.
author: Hamza E.

description:
This place is a solid lunch spot in the Financial District.
I order the avocado falafel sandwich - as it was highly recommended by fellow Yelpers. This sandwich did not disappoint. Loaded with crispy falafel and ripe avocado, it got a little messy while I was eating it - but it was so delicious i could not put it down.

It cost less than $8 and the portions are great. I could only finish half of it.

I think Sunrise is a great addition to the area and I absolutely love their food. It is prepared well and the ingredients seem fresh.
author: Vanessa W.

description:
yeah - i'll pass on this next time.

The lamb is tougher than shoe leather, 
the prices are kind of high, and way too high for the quality of what I got.

Sorry if this is a little harsh, but you'd be unhappy too if you just threw away half of your lunch because it was inedible.
Seriously, one of the most disappointing Lamb Shawarma's that I've ever had.
Congrats guys, you made the list.
author: Hans H.

description:
This is 100% NOT the best falafel in the city, contrary to the dozens of signs claiming "best falafel" awards (someone's compensating!)  

The falafel tastes oily and metallic - not fresh - like all the other mediocre falafel I've had.  And I've eaten there in the height of the lunch hour, when the food should be at its freshest.

The best falafel in the city is just a few blocks away at Oasis Grill, corner of at 4th and Howard (also, one other location - same falafel recipe - is on Drumm St.)

You can also get better falafel at these locations:
Ali Babba Cafe (Valencia between 18th & 19th)
Yummas (Irving St between 8th and 9th aves)
author: Chris B.

description:
Despite its name, it is not a "Deli" by any means, in fact it is a middle eastern fast food restaurant. This is not a negative point, but I believe a Deli should feature delicatessen food. 

I ordered the Chicken Schwarma sandwich. It was immediately quite disappointing, as it was poorly wrapped, and proceeded to soak through and destroy the sandwich which I finished with a knife and fork. The filling itself was cheap tasting and nothing special. I felt satisfied after, but I would not bother coming back.
author: Jordan C.

description: The folks who work there are nice.. but when it comes to food, no bueno. Walked through the rain to get there for 15 minutes on my lunch break..ordered a schwarma lamb/beef plate and the food was cold. 20 minutes later I felt sick, then I'm in the bathroom lol the low rating is for the simple fact that there's no excuse to serve a dish cold when it's supposed to be at least warm.
author: Allen K.

description: It is so nice that this place is conveniently located right across the street from me.  I love their falafels.  This time I got the falafel plate which is basically a falafel with it being in the pita.  It was good and I'm comfortably full.  I haven't tried any of their other dishes.  But will one day.
author: Liz D.

description: I visit Sunrise Deli at least 2 or 3 times a week on my lunch break since it's about a 3 minute walk from my office building. I always have trouble choosing from their menu because of the wide variety of food they have. I usually always go for either their lamb and chicken shawarma sandwich, with their hot sauce and grab a half dozen falafel to bring back to the office because they're just so good. The wait for your food is no longer than 5-6 minutes and the customer service is always on point. The employees there always seem to be happy to help you, even at their busiest rush hours. Awesome lunch spot with cool art and paintings on the wall. Visit this spot if you ever have the chance!
author: Corry G.

description:
If you come before 12:30, you can beat the lunch hour rush. 

Plentiful seating, great pricing (this place makes it possible to get a decent lunch in SF for less than $10), and the food ain't so bad either. I got the lamb shwarma and the hummus was delicious. Good place to sit down and eat or grab a quick meal to go. Also super convenient to BART and MUNI.
author: liz c.

description:
Terrible lamb shawarma from their food truck. Why would they even serve something this bad? The lamb was so bland, thick, and overcooked that it seemed like they had just boiled it for an hour and served it just like that. The pickled cabbage was sour and not in a good way, and the entire thing was drenched in yogurt sauce that dripped like a leaking faucet. The only decent thing about this schwarma was the pita, which I doubt they made themselves. I tossed out everything inside and just ate the pita alone.

This has been the only meal from anywhere that was so bad that I had to write a review for it on yelp in hope that they will see this and learn how to properly cook meat, or just stop serving that awful overpriced item ($8).

That's not the only thing that made me angry. The service was ambivalent. They took my order, and within 2 seconds handed me a drippy, wet schwarma rolled in foil. That shows how much time and effort they put into their food (literally 2 seconds). When I went to look for a napkin to clean the mess they just handed me, I found that their dispensers were inside the truck window and away from the customer. Why on earth? Are they trying to save napkins? I reached for one dispenser and a man inside grabbed it from me and handed me a few. I thought that was so strange, and only fueled my disappointment with this place.

They may have good falafels here, but I'll never know because I'm never going back.
author: Stephanie P.

description: I just purchased a lamb shawerma and it was nasty...the meat looks like it was grounded not cut(like before) on giant meat grill and it was cold and lettuce was kinda brownish....it was total waste $8...not recommended.
author: Lar G.

description:
as a NYC transplant - I was thrilled when I saw a falafel place near work. It's the perfect little meal sometimes - especially for a quick lunch. 

My problem with Sunrise is not so much taste - it was really good, It was just the way it was served to me. 

I ordered the "Super" thinking it would have all the fixings I require, only to get a burrito! - what is with this city and the burritos!? I just wanted a stuffed-to-the-point-of-breading pita sandwich, instead I got a middle eastern mission burrito.  Disappointed - but not dissatisfied - I'll go again, but order a plate this time.
author: Christian C.

description:
Good food during lunch. Conveniently located near where I work. I usually get the shawerma and dolma or falafel, all together pretty solid food. Will continue to eat here.  

Price is reasonable. Food is good. I stay happy!
author: Tom L.

description:
So the food is good, but it's way overpriced.  Way way way overpriced.

And I was all right with it for a few minutes because it reminded me so much of places in Dowtown Berkeley, and almost all food in Downtown Berkeley is way overpriced.  Way way way overpriced.  

But then I thought about it, and wasn't I just killing time while waiting for the elusive 10-Townsend?  Why should I be spending so much of my money here?

And then I did a really bad thing; I resolved to write a scathing two-star review because it was owned by the same people who own Oasis Grill in Downtown Berkeley, and that place is kind of mid-level evil incarnate with a cheap red bow on top.  Then I thought better of it.  I enjoyed my meal that was way overpriced.  Way way way overpriced.

And I listened to the strange conversation that the three anesthesiologists at the next table (seriously, I'm not making this stuff up) were having; and I thought about the fact that it had been almost exactly one year since my appendectomy, the first (but sadly not the last) time in my life I had been put under full anesthesia, had spent a night in a hospital (eight nights total), had thought seriously about dying in a realistic way.  And the casualness with which these doctors were discussing and debating the drug that killed Michael Jackson.  

And the decor.  And then I looked again at the logo, and Sunrise isn't owned by the same people who own Oasis Grill; Sunrise Deli is owned by the same people who own the Sunrise Deli in Berkeley south of campus, on Bancroft.  And that put my mind at ease.  I had been there, and while it wasn't spectacular, it wasn't horrible either.  And the people were nice.

So here's the thing.  It's way overpriced.  Way way way overpriced.

But it's all right, and sometimes--just sometimes--it's fun to begin every paragraph with a coordinating conjunction.
author: John S.

description:
You know that feeling when you're in the FiDi (I hate myself for calling it that) and you're starving for lunch, but none of the typical sandwich/salad places sound appetizing at all? 
Then it's time to dine like a Bedouin and get you some middle-east. 
While it's the typical, somewhat bland fare of the region, the ingredients are fresh, healthy (the lamb is quite fatty though), and satisfying. It's a great change from the normal lunch that will leave you appeased by not feeling like a fatty. 
If you're not feeling too adventurous, give the chicken kebab a try and be happy.
author: Muz H.

description:
I had the vegetarian plate. The falafel was one of the most delicious I've ever had. Nice and crispy on the outside. The hummus and babaghanouj were also tasty. 

But what really kind of threw things off was their Tomato and Cucumber salad and Cucumber salad. IT WAS WAY TOO VINEGAR-Y. So much that it overpowered the whole plate.  Now I don't have problems with vinegar or sour tasting foods, spices and sauces...but it seemed whenever I tried to pair it up with anything on the plate, it was still a bitter overkill.

I'd go back but I'd probably stay clear from the salads unless it was just someone who accidentally poured lots of vinegar our sour stuff on it today. Or maybe I got the bottom of the mix. Still, it should've been a balanced plate.
author: Vee A.

description:
3 stars bc i mostly am veggie, but i tore up the lamb moussaka. As usual, I found a few things to whine about that took away from the star power:
1. Ordered a size of babaganoush, it tasted like they dumped tahini into hummus..no trace of eggplant to be found
2. COLD pita. a misdemeanor.

I do really like this spot. I always get the felafel deluxe with avocado and grilled eggplant. I was in the mood for a nice, greasy babaganoush today tho...the search continues.
author: Royal S.

description:
Hummus was good, falafel was nasty. 
The food was pretty bad overall. Surprising because a lot of people reccomend this place. 
In addition to the rancid falafel, I didn't like much else on the plate aside from teh hummus, baba ghanooj, and the tabouleh. 
The lentils and rice was cold, which may be acceptable to serve that way, but most places I have been to in Ca serve it warm.  Teh olives were awful. They are very tiny and 90% pit!
The dolmas was okay, I've never been a huge fan of dolmas though. 
Teh cucumber/tomato salad was fist sized chunks of these. With no dressing. Too large to eat with the pita, and not really a salad by itself. 
I also was underwhelmed with the pita. Not even heated up, just cold pita in foil. 
Overall, I think it is safe to say this place is dreadful and I will not be going back.
author: Russ D.

description:
If I didn't see them making the falafel while I waited, I would swear they were lacing them with illegal substances.  These are the best falafels in the city and perhaps on the planet.  Beyond the flavor, they have found the perfect ratio between fluffy moistness on the inside and crunchy shell on the outside.

I rotate between avocado falafels and super falafels to give myself the illusion of variety.
author: Mark F.

description: Ordered a avocado falafel to-go.  When I arrived back at my office two blocks away, I discovered brown avocado and falafel all over my bag.  They packaged the sandwich cut open, allowing for all the juices to seep through the paper bag- I had to end up eating it in a bowl, picking pieces of paper out from each bite.
author: maggie w.

description: I was hoping that this could be my new Shawarma place because it's much closer to me but unfortunately it didn't live up to my expectations.  I think they had a new crew working there because it took me a while to get my order in and then it took a while for it to come out even though the place wasn't that crowded.  The Shawarma was just ok too.  It lacked any real flavor.  Other items on their menu might be better but I'll stick with my go to.
author: Blake B.

description: Let me tell you something, this place is legit. I felt like I got on a southwest flight..went across the seas...and ate me a nice homemade felafel . HUGE portion sizes, wait is quick, and the food is delicious and filling. Good lunch in the financial district. Usually there is seating.
author: Yumna B.

description: It really is great falafel! But word to the wise...just order the regular falafel sandwich and ask for everything on the side instead of the falafel plate. Only difference the ad a cucumber salad to the plate but charge $4 more
author: Amanda C.

description:
Cheap.
Tasty.
Vegetarian friendly.
Clean.
Not crowded.
Generously portioned.
Fairly speedy.
Generous with the hummus.
(Sunrise Deli is all of these)

Romantic.
Super friendly.
Rambunctious.
(Sunrise Deli is not all of these)
author: Amanda F.

description:
Went here for lunch today with a LivingSocial "Instant" deal. $6 for $10 worth of food.

I ordered the chicken schwarma pita to go, along with two falafel balls. The falafel was very good. I enjoyed my two balls. As for the schwarma, it was mediocre. The sauces lacked flavor, the portion was small, and it was already soggy by the time I got it upstairs (and i work right next door). If you want falafel, go here. If you want schwarma, go to Baladie.
author: Kevin H.

description:
Is it a good falafel?  Definitely yes - nice and crunchy shell and moist, tender and flavorful inside.  I loved the inclusion of marinated cabbage - so good!  And they even had mostly ripe tomatoes too.

But - it it the best falafel in the city?  I am afraid not.  The pita shell was very flabby and thin, although I loved the nice touch of having the pita cut in half and each half wrapped separately.

Hadi's on Battery gets my vote for the best falafel in San Francisco, as well as the best gyro in San Francisco.

Anyone want to challenge them to a throw-down?
author: .Hon H.

description:
At $12 with tax for a lamb shawarma platter, I expected much better as I go to Ayola and Baladie pretty frequently for my fidi lunch. 

The food itself was edible, but nothing really that great. The lamb was dry and chewy, the hummus was passable, and the pita was.. pita. 

Especially when Subway is doing the $5 footlong promo just a couple doors down, I can't see why I'd see myself back again. I do have to say their falafel is quite good, but just not my preferred lunch time fare.
author: Dave C.

description: Placed a to go order of falafel. Falafel tasted very authentic and was really fresh. They even brought my order out to my car so I didnt have to go through the trouble of finding parking...excellent customer service!!!
author: Mel I.

description:
The falafel's are good but  Baladie Cafe around the corner has overall a much higher quality of food.  

What makes this place so disappointing is the service.The woman behind the counter is angry at the world. It took over 15 minutes for my boyfriend and I to get two veggie combo plates. While other patrons entered, she told them "you have to wait!" just to order their food. We won't be returning.
author: Whitney A.

description:
Not as cheap or as good as the place in NYC I used to frequent almost daily, but cheap and good enough for around here, definitely.
They need to work on speeding up service a bit, but that will come in time.
The falafel are handmade on site and excellent.
If they priced the falafel sandwich at $5 including tax, the line would be out the door.  Of course, it practically is already (the line, not the sandwich).
author: dan s.

description:
When looking for some Middle Eastern food in the FiDi, Sunrise Deli is the place to go.

I ordered the Avocado Falafel (Avocado, Hummus, Lettuce, Tomatoes, Tahini Sauce, served in a pita bread). It was nice and crispy on the outside and extremely flavorful on the inside. They give you two decent slices of avocado and the whole pita is filled to the brim. There was a heaping amount of hummus inside which was super delicious. 

Overall, I enjoyed my lunch at Sunrise Deli as the food was good and the service was fast. The portions are good and won't leave you feeling bogged down the rest of the afternoon.
author: Myron J.

description: Average food and overpriced. For $13 you get a bowl with some meat, tomatoes and onions sprinkled in and covered in hummus. Oh and a piece of pita bread.  Not bad but I'm not going back. There are plenty of other middle eastern options like kvivar cafe at Pine and Kearney.
author: W P.

description:
If they didn't make claims about having the best super falafel sandwich in the city, I would have given them another star.  I already had my suspicions, just because I'm pretty sure I know the best falafel sandwich is at Ali Baba's Cave on 19th and Valencia.  Also, this place is in the FiDi, which automatically means the food is under suspicion.

But hey, it was alright. Can't complain about the actual quality of anything, just the fact that it was 90% falafel with a tiny hint of everything else (lettuce, tomatoes, hummus, eggplant). If they could just put more of the other stuff in there, I would be a lot more likely to tack on some stars.  When you order a "super" anything, you kind of expect a lot more.  It felt very regular.
author: Mari C.

description:
This review is for Sunrise Deli's food truck at the SF Flea Market...

While edible, their lamb shawarma sandwich was the worst I ever had.  It had essentially no taste.  My wife had the same thing...  not good in any way.  Now to be fair, my son like his.  But then he likes almost anything smothered in Tabasco sauce.  Thus, his opinion is at the extreme end of the bell curve. To me and my wife...  It was a complete waste of $24.  When I asked for hot sauce, 5 minutes later I got chili flakes freshly mixed with olive oil - not spicy in and way. 

Conclusion...  Save your money and try another food truck at the flea market!
author: Ooo O.

description: Lamb Shawarma sandwich! Delicious! It's a cool place to go for lunch. There is a short wait but the food is always pretty fresh and authentic!
author: Vickie Z.

description:
Meh. There's better out there.
Ambience: Clean hole in the wall joint with claustrophobic seating. Went here for lunch and there was no place for more than 4 people to sit together.
Service: You order at the counter and fetch it yourself before trying to find a seat.
Food: Mediocre but lots of it. I had the chicken kabob plate.  Ended up with way more than I could eat but I didn't really want to take it with me to eat later. The chicken was under-seasoned and lacking in flavor. It's not like it was bad, just not anything I'd go back for.
Price: If you're okay with average taste then it's good for the money.
I have had much better Mediterranean in many other places.
author: Geoff A.

description:
I highly recommend the falafel (plate, super, regular, avocado -- whatever way you order it!) After my first time here I could not have my falafel cravings satisfied anywhere else. They are perfectly crisp and flavorful. And you can't beat the falafel wrapped in pita with avocado. A California twist on a classic to-go meal.

The lamb (schwarma)  is a little tough and both the pita and lavash bread falls apart when you're eating the wraps, but it is some of the most tasty middle eastern cuisine I've tried. Delicious!
author: Katelyn M.

description:
***THIS REVIEW IS FOR THE LAMB SHAWERMA ONLY***

I had a homemade sandwich filled with delicious turkey and avo ready for my consumption when a bunch of co-workers decided to go out for lunch! Not wanting to be anti-social I joined in. I should have just brought my sandwich to eat here instead. Or ordered something else.

Everything but the lamb in this pita 'wich was delicious. The lamb - not so much. The meat was dry, tough, and didn't even have very good flavor. I've been to the Berkeley location and have always found their falafels, veggie plates, and chicken shawermas delicious! Not sure if this was a bad day or not, but boy was I disappointed.
author: Jennifer W.

description: I have only had the falafel, however it was really good. Comes in a pita pocket with tomatoes and pickled vegetables.
author: Jennifer J.

description:
yummy vegetarian plate- cold cucumber and tomato salad, great falafel, hummus, tahini, a few other salads...such variety and all of it tastes fresh and delicious.  The place is small, the service is fast, the portions are just what i'm looking for in a lunch.  

I've also used them for catering a few times and I highly recommend this!  they create a very unique platter of the above vegetarian options and I know everyone always appreciates something besides the usual sandwich or pizza catering in this area.  My only complaint about the catering was that they didn't give us plates or forks because we didn't ask for them...what?  I guess I thought this was assumed for caterers, but oh well.  The hot falafel more than made up for it.
author: Luthien N.

description: This place is awful. I love middle eastern food and since I work a block a way I've pondered going here for lunch quite a few times but given the reviews I was hesitant to try it. I ordered and my food came out super quick! too quick I wasn't sure what to think. I brought it back to my office which again is a block a way a three min walk at most. And My chicken was freezing cold and sitting in a soup of hummus and grease I ate a bit of it and couldn't stomach it. It was terrible. I think I'm gonna be sick. I will never come back to this place again and I suggest you avoid it too.
author: Sasha A.

description: Wow.  I just had the worst Lamb Shawarma I have ever had in my life from this place.  Did you guys find a week old dead cat outside and throw it on a frying pan?  Seriously I could hardly chew the meat, when there was meat, there was a large amount of grissle and now my stomach is upset.   I'm appalled that you have the audacity to sell this.  Maybe they have edible food here, but I will not return to find out.  This gets my vote for WORST food experience I have had in the bay area.  EPIC FAIL.
author: Bryan M.

description:
I am a big believer in yelp and love all the help all the readers have provided me over the years.

I owe you guys alot. Here is my first start.

Avoid this place at all cost. I went in on this cold day hoping to get some lamb yumminess. 

I was given cardboard. Seriously, my food came in two minutes. I should have gotten a hint when I asked for it to be extra spicy, and instead of hot sauce in the schwarma, it came on the side.

My first bite was like biting into leather. The lamb was the worst thing I have ever tried in years. There was no hummus in the schwerma, and I ended up throwing the entire thing away. It was cold and I am surprised they are in business. Seriously, listen to the reviews. Go to Oasis- it is worth the wait. 

This place is horseshit. They should be ashamed for serving this.  Save your money and your stomach.

They should be shut down.  They are lucky I ordered it to go. If I sat there and ate this, I would have raised a ruckus.
author: Gaurav A.

description: terrible chicken shwarma. please dont come here
author: Patricia K.

description: This location and all the other Sunrise Delis have the best falafel I've ever had.  Also, just tried the kufta kebab here.  It's great.  This is one of the better inexpensive options around this area, IMO.
author: Bryan S.

description:
Great falafel and lentil soup! I have gone twice now and been pleased both times. The first time I got the falafel sandwich. The second time I split a falafel with a friend and got a bowl of lentil soup. The soup was very large, I couldn't even finish it. I'd recommend going with a friend and splitting a bowl of soup and a falafel.

The staff was really nice and the food was delicious!
author: Emily K.

description: There are a few places like this near my office, but this one is definitely the top 1 or 2!  I usually get the Vegetarian Platter (which is 2nd only to Ayola on Mission), but today I tried the avocado falafel sandwich - omg yum!  The combo of avocados & their amazing falafel is to die along with the dressing of hummus, lots of yummy lettuce & tomatoes...yum!  Stuffed...and happy.
author: Kim A.

description:
The first time I went there months ago, I ordered a falafal. Not too bad, but kind of tasteless...certainly not the best I've ever had. This time, I had a hankering for a lamb shawarma. I was too lazy to walk to Drumm street to get, what I know to be, an excellent version, and so walked the short distance to Sunrise. As before, I was disappointed. But this time, the disappointment caused me to write a yelp review. 

The main culprit was the lamb...it lacked all taste, was chewy and seemed to have been microwaved. Not acceptable. The veggies also lacked any real flavor, even though they were pickled. The only part that had any taste was the hummas. And for $8, the shawarma itself was a little on the stingy side, if you ask me. No next time for this place.
author: Heather S.

description:
Best falafel in town? Probably, but that's not saying very much. You can easily make better at home, but if you're in this neighborhood, you're probably not home, so for those times, there's this. 

Everything's a little bland, the pitas are a little thin, and the lines are a little too long to be worth it, but I'd go back.
author: Nicholas J.

description:
Hurray - a new lunch option nearby, and Middle Eastern food, to boot! I was in the mood for something different and my lamb shwarma hit the spot. Loaded with lots of lamb, the stuffed pita came with a couple olives and a few tasty slices of pickled turnip for $6.99. 

The sandwich was good, but on my 2nd trip I took advantage of the great-looking deals on the appetizer menu - 6 falafel for $3.49 and the 8" "Armenian pizza" for $2.99. The falafel were very good and came with a small cup of hummus for dipping. The pizza was cheese-less but topped with ground lamb, tomato, and red pepper, and it definitely had some kick. My third trip focused on the thick wedge of spinach pie ($3.99). Next time, I'll try the thyme pizza.

Atmosphere was a little stark, but the paintings on the wall really helped provide some character. The cherrywood (?) furniture and faux malachite tabletops were very nice. I appreciated the reusable utensils and glasses for eat-in, along with the self-serve water pitchers in the soda case.

Sunrise Deli has definitely risen into the upper echelon of my list of places to have lunch!

TRIVIA: Falafel originated in Egypt, made with fava beans, though as it spread throughout the Middle East, chickpeas (garbanzo beans) become a common base also. The word "falafel" translates from Arabic roughly as an adjective meaning "fluffy/crunchy", which perfectly fits the falafel balls here at Sunrise.
author: Bill B.

description: The new location recently opened in Downtown SOMA. For lunch, we ordered the chicken shawarma plate ($10.99) and the chicken was literally swimming in hummus and tahini sauce. Nevertheless, the fiance was really happy with the dish. He loved dipping the pita bread into the sauce, which was delicious. The chicken was a bit dry and had a bit of a burnt taste in my opinion so hence, the 3 stars.
author: Tina T.

description:
One comment sticks out in my mind as I contemplate whether to give two or three stars. It was the reaction from my sister when I expressed a slight bit of disdain for being charged $0.50 for lavash instead of pita bread.

"Didn't you downgrade your bread?"

Well yes I did, and I got charged for it. And in retrospect, even though my chicken shawarma was good, and I greatly appreciate they got the no onions, no tahini right, I'm not sure it was worth $8. That the lady working the register barely let out a thank you and let off quite the dismissive vibe when taking my order didn't help things.

Not a bad choice, but I've experienced better.
author: Jason B.

description:
I've been here a couple times, and like that they stuff fries/potatoes into their super falafel wrap.  Other places nearby, like Ayola and Baladie, offer fries separately.  Here, it's like an all-in-one meal.  It leaves me full afterward, unlike Oasis.  

The prices are decent, and the dining area is no frills (more seating up the stairs).  The place also doesn't get as stuffy as its rivals that I've noted previously--maybe because they're a lil larger.  For a weekday lunch in the FiDi, Sunrise has become my go-to for falafel cravings.
author: Marsha Z.

description: I LOVE sunrise deli. They have one of the best falafel wraps I've ever had, and for an affordable price too! Servers are super nice and accommodating.
author: Julia H.

description:
I'm not a complicated man (well, only for the purposes of this review).

All I ever want is an Avocado Falafel Sandwich and a cranberry Nantucket Nectar. So who has my back? Sunrise of course. They're consistently tasty, quick and satisfying so what else is there to say?

My only complaint is that the sandwich falls apart too easily and I often eat half of it with a fork. Never did stop me though!
author: Ryan V.

description: I ordered a lamb shawarma in pita sandwich and it came out cold and tasteless. Not only that but the lamb was dry and chewy like gum. There are other good Indian places nearby, I'm not going here again
author: Chris W.

description: I feel deceived by the signs in the front claiming that it is the Best Falafel.  I came in to try a sample and it was okkkkkk, but definitely not the best.  I ordered a chicken shawarma and my friend ordered the lamb.  Both of us agreed that it's very bland and flavorless, my chicken was also dry.
author: Emmie N.

description: lamb shawarma. who would think lots of lamb would be a bad thing but it was. The lamb was tough like over dried thick jerky. Almost impossible to eat. Cost is too high for what it is. Would definitely stay away
author: Kenny L.

description: Pretty bad. Nice, friendly, prompt service, but the veggie mezze platter was the worst I've had in San Francisco (out of a sample size of ~10-15), and relatively high-priced to boot. Kind of a bummer.
author: JR H.

description:
Veggie Combo Plate.  YES.

Sunrise Deli, I can see you from my office window and when I look out at you, I smile.  The best falafel spot around.

Babba gahnoush is so smoky, smooth and tasty; salads are flavorful with lots of options; falafel is perfectly crunchy but still soft on the inside.  So much food - never can finish it.

And when you go, make sure to ask for their excellent hot sauce.
author: Myla M.

description: Love this place! Probably some of the best falafels i've ever had and their lebanese style sandwiches are also super delicious.  Perfect for grabbing lunch.  Not the best for eating in but definitely taking to go!
author: Holly M.

description:
If you're looking for a delicious and reasonably priced meal that doesn't fall into one of the played-out categories of subs, burgers or pizza, look no further than this hidden gem located in the FiDi.

After hearing good things from a friend about one of their other locations, I decided to give Sunrise a try during my lunch hour.  The place was packed but my cravings for genuine Mediterranean food at the time would not allow me to leave. Despite the rush, the employees were very efficient and I didn't have to wait long at all. The man who took my order offered me a free falafel (bonus points for free food!) and I cannot describe how tasty it was.  I promised myself I'd get the falafel sandwich during my next visit.

I ordered the chicken shawerma sandwich on lavish bread instead of pita and it literally took my breath away! The meat was tender and succulent. The veggies were crisp and garden-fresh. The tahini sauce had a pleasantly-distinct taste to it.  Best of all, it was a perfect-sized wrap.  I went back to work without the sluggish feeling that Subway and local Taquerias usually gives me.

I seriously regret not discovering this place sooner.  Sunrise, you have officially earned yourself a regular customer.  Five stars for professional and courteous service meets delicious, affordable food.
author: Mahmoud E.

description:
I didn't have time to make my lunch today and am so tired of the same old places to eat downtown...so decided to try something new. Sunrise Deli is right across the street from my work so thought what the heck. I am eating the vegetarian combo plate OMG DELICIOUS! It comes with Hummus, Tabouli, Bagaghanuj, Rice & Lentils, Tomato & Cucumber Salad, with Falafel & Dolma served with Pita Bread. YUMMY! It is $9 a plate (I know, a bit pricey in this economy) but you get a lot of food (can feed 2 people). Totally worth it. Now I have leftovers for tomorrow ha ha...

If you are not a vegetarian, no problem, they have other items on the menu: Sandwiches, soups, kabab plates, etc. They also do catering. The staff are very friendly too.
author: Beth S.

description:
Their falafels deserve 5 stars, hands down.  Crisy outside, flavorful inside.  I had them alone on the side and in their Avocado Falafel sandwich.  Big heapings of avocado and crispy falafel in a pita.  Absolutely delish!  

So why do you ask am I giving this place 4 stars?  Well, their other items, such as the lamb schwerma, just didn't make the cut.  The lamb was dry and it wasn't worth the $7-8 that I paid.

Their falalefels are definitely going into my routine lunch places to go.
author: Yun W.

description:
Sunrise Deli is by a wide margin the best falafel I've ever had, and that's not because I haven't had much falafel I'm constantly searching for falafel as good or better than sunrise's and nothing comes close. I go there almost everyday on my lunch breaks and it never gets old. I recommend it to all my friends and no one has ever been underwhelmed.
I started out getting the avocado falafel every time and I still enjoy it whenever I do decide to go that route but lately I have been getting into the veggie delight sandwich it is amazing and only available at the 2nd street location. Do yourself a favor and go get one.
author: Sam M.

description: There are a lot of Sunrise Deli's throughout the bay, and I have no idea how the others are, but this one on 2nd street makes one of the best falafel sandwiches in town.  They sometimes stockpile the falafels (bad sign) but they go through so much volume, that they're always basically right out of the fryer. I've never been disappointed. Perfect texture, green with lots of parsley, crispy on the outside. I strongly recommend adding hot sauce to your order. I add extra tahini because I'm a tahini nut, but that makes for a messy (yet delicious) sandwich.
author: Erik P.

description: It's been a long time since I've had a good shawarma. The Lamb Shawarma was super delicious here. I was really happy with the outcome, especially since I'm sometimes really hard to please. The texture of the lamb was quite perfect. And the ingredients used tasted really fresh and how the ingredients were proportioned in the finished product just made the meal a delight. Even though the price was a bit STEEP for the dish, I can't wait to visit again.
author: Rosie M.

description:
Great falafel, the best I've had in SOMA! The first time I went here I had the falafel sandwich, which was excellent. The falafel are perfectly crisp and well spiced on the inside. The tahini sauce and the hot sauce (the latter sold separately) are both great accompaniments.

Yesterday I tried to branch out to see if falafel is the only dish that Sunrise Deli has mastered and was again impressed with their vegetarian combo.
