It includes dolma, hummus, tabuleh, babaghanuj, tomatoes, cucumbers, and - most importantly - 2 pieces of falafel (I probably wouldn't have been able to branch out without it!) The babaghanuj was particularly good, it was much more creamy than at other Mediterranean places. The plate was jam packed, I was very satisfied upon completion.
author: Adam B.

description: The lamb/beef shawarma plate is awful. It's super cold hummus with some of the meat on top, 3 olives and a couple of tiny tomato cubes. Avoid avoid avoid. The pita was OK.
author: Chris C.

description:
OK, I've got it down now: Super falafel wrap, baba ganoush instead of eggplant, and no potatoes (can't taste 'em in there anyway, so why bother?). This one comes in lavash instead of pita and I am all over that shit. Soooooo tasty. So five stars for that item, at a reasonable price, no less.

Minus one: I've had a few other things. I was underwhelmed by the veggie combo platter...just wasn't a fan of enough of the things on there (though it is HUGE). I will just be sticking to the aforementioned phenom of a sandwich from here on out. Ooo...I must try the fresh made pita chips sometime though...they always look so crispily fried delicious when I go in.
author: Jasmine F.

description: Yummy and cheap! Good wraps, perfect for lunch time at work. They often have an instant Groupon deal for $5 off or something if you spend $10, but even that is too much for me.
author: christine c.

description:
Chicken Shawarma 'sandwich' - 
Ingredients here are tasty & fresh, but the sandwich on pita completely falls apart, has way too much lettuce, and not enough sauce.
author: Dan C.

description:
Wow. Good job to Sunrise Deli for turning the Old Dirty Ming's into something spectacular.

I've had my eye on the sign for quite some time and finally got a chance to try it today. The falafel plate was a bit steep for my budget... and I was eventually going to turn it into a sandwich anyway, so I opted for the $6.99 Avocado Falafel.

First off, I wanted to taste their falafel and he hands me one to sample and it was pretty friggin good. Tasty fried outer crust with a taste of sesame and chickpea goodness. Not too oily and it has a consistency similar to a well produced hush puppy. Nonetheless, I was sold.

I was even more shocked to see how huge the sandwich was. There's a total of 4 falafels, with lettuce, tahini, hummus and 1/2 an avocado in a huge pita. This is definitely enough for 2 people to share, and trust: I am a heffer. 

The flavor was great... except maybe the assembly of the falafel was a bit rushed. All the hummus was in the bottom which resulted in a leaky sandwich. but I really can't complain. There's a Mediteranean place steps away from my office and it is a blessing and a curse... a blessing, that I can satisfy my mediteranean flair on any given day. A Curse: because I will probably do this every. single. day. FML.
author: Alyson C.

description:
Hands down the best falafel in San Francisco. My friend and I split the falafel platter which came with pickled beets, a pretty good hummus and another sauce that I wasn't as keen on...but man that falafel!

Perfectly crisp on the outside and moist on the inside and so flavorful.

Decently priced and the staff was great about assuring us that our meal was vegan.
author: Bee D.

description: Just an OK place. I have read this was voted the best falafel place in the city. I did not try their falafel so I can not say anything about this. But as far as other things it is not the best place. I know of at least one that is better: Taboun on Parnassus Ave. I had Chicken Shawarma. It was greasy and cold. We had to ask to warm it up. I would not go there again.
author: Sophie N.

description: 1/2 dozen falafels for $4 that taste great with that hummus sauce sounds like a great deal to me. I also a chicken kebab sandwich which was great. My only small complaint about that is the pita bread they put the chicken is is a bit filmsy. Not a bad place to pick up lunch as it's not far from work for me.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
The best falafel I've had in the city. Get it deluxe style with the eggplant and fries. The tahini sauce is on point.

Friendly service. Upstairs seating. Clean restrooms.
author: Judy L.

description:
I always go  with the Veggie Combo- Tabouli, Babaghanuj, Hummus, Tahini, Tomato and Cucumber Salad, with Falafel and Dolma, served with pita bread. You get alot of food, which usually amounts to two meals for me. Win!

The falafel are always fresh and I love the pickled purple things- turnips? They are pretty quick to get your meal to you, even when they are slammed during the lunch hour. Prices are a little on the high side, but it's to be expected for the area.
author: Karly F.

description:
I can't begin to tell you how excited I was to learn that Sunrise Deli had opened a location downtown.  I lived near the Sunset location for about four years and had always held it in high esteem; the shawerma was good at that location, but the falafel was the best in town.

When I finally lunched at the SOMA location, I was pleased as punch to discover that, not only was the falafel as good as the other location, but the shawerma was even better!  Sure, I have a few minor gripes (why no pickled turnips with takeout orders?), but for my money this is either THE best or the second best Middle Eastern place in town (it's tough to choose between this and Truly Med on Valencia).
author: joe p.

description: I've had shawarmas from here and they are all right.  I had the baba ghanouj another day, however, and it was very strange and concerning.  Unlike any other baba ghanouj I've had elsewhere, it was very sour, like it had gone bad or something.  At first, I hoped it was just some kind of variation of regular baba ghanouj, and I tried to eat a few spoonfuls of it.  Soon after, I came to my senses, remembering how I had done the same with a certain sour-tasting tiramisu in an expensive restaurant in Napa; I was simultaneously throwing up and having violent diarrhea by the end of that dinner.  Note to self:  Stick to the shawarmas - steer clear of the baba ghanouj.
author: K L.

description:
I had already bought my lunch, but was keen to have just one falafel (kinda like the bag of chips to go with the sandwich). Like the previous reviewer, just want to have one before I commit to a whole roll!

I walked in and asked if they'll sell me one - he gave me one on the house. 

A little over fried but pretty damn good:) 

I used to go to Old Ming's a lot (dodgy Chinese is always good!)... different cuisine of course but I am fairly sure I'll be back to Sunrise Deli for more.
author: Joyce L.

description: I get falafels here a lot, they are impossibly crispy and delicious! I don't know what they fry them in but it's really good. Five stars for consistently excellent falafel. However I went there today with a friend, they got a lamb shwarma and every bite of lamb was gristle except for the last bite, because that was a huge piece of fat. It was rediculous, he ended up spitting out all of the meat bite by bite because it was like chewing an inner tube and it would not break down. Two stars for serving inner-tube meat! Tender meat is the whole idea of a shwarma!
author: theHAMMER H.

description: Great solid lunch place for $10 or less. I like their super falafel sandwich. I asked to get mine spicy but didn't find it was spicy at all. Portion size is a bit smaller compared to other falafel serving joints but I would have to say they win flavor-wise.
author: Amy N.

description:
3.5 stars, but since I'm generous, I'm rounding it up to 4.

I've had:

Lamb shawarma - Good flavor, but messy.  Comes inside a thin pita, so it fell apart without even trying.  I guess they gave me the meat closer to the heat, because the lamb pieces I got were on the crispy/crunchy side.

Avocado falafel - The falafel itself is amazing.  I mean, it was the most deep fried falafel I've ever had.  You can get the regular falafel without avocado for $5.99, if I remember correctly, and get avocado for a buck fifty more.

I love avocado, but it felt and tasted like they only gave me 1/4 of my favorite fruit for that buck fiddy.  Lesson learned: getting the regular next time and bringing my own friggin avocado.

Also messy.  They cut the pita in half so that it's easier to eat, but dude, the pita is so thin it just falls apart in my hands, causing greasy falafel pieces to fall onto my premium denim.  That's just not cool.
author: L Y.

description: BEST Falafel anywhere. My friend even said that this is better than some falafels in the actual middle east. The other plates and wraps are decent, but much better than other similar places near Market st.
author: Shawn T.

description: Pretty Terrible.  That was my Chicken Sharma experience here.  The chicken was so dry, it was more like jerky.  They use a crumbling pita pocket instead of lavash flat bread, and there is zero kick in their sauce.  And for $7.50, I'd like a little more food.  Another customers Falafel looked better as did their salad .... but I would never go back for another butchered sharma.
author: Dyon Z.

description:
At the risk of sounding like a Mediterranean food harlot, Sunrise is one of a great many Greeky places I now frequent.  I'm Italian, okay?  If I don't get a certain quota of olive oil, I shrivel up and blow away.  While I don't consider Sunrise my fave, it has its own lovable quirks and specialties that keep me coming back.

Sunrise is not such a good place for groups, but if you're after an intimate-but-casual lunch for a friend or a fan of small spaces (I personally find them cozy!), there should be nothing stopping you from enjoying this ultra-casual setting for a sit-down meal.  And really, if you're working in SOMA or the FiDi and wearing a suit all day, doesn't it feel good to hunker down to a laminated table and stuff your pretty face with falafel?  Go ahead, I won't tell.  Oh, fine.  You can get it to go if you must.

Speaking of falafel, it's really some of the best I've had.  It's not greasy, but it is delightfully crunchy on the outside and creamy on the inside.  Like, creamier than any other falafel I've had.  This, of course, takes care of one of the issues one can take with falafel: it's just a lot of chickpea.  Sunrise adds in a couple other flavors to the mix to keep things interesting.  My personal favorite is the avocado falafel, and my boyfriend goes for the super falafel.  Point being, adding more fat and starch to your fat and starch is clearly the best way to go.  Their pitas are artfully arranged with just enough avocado (if that's your thing), a generous amount of tahini (or possibly a hummus-tahini mixture thing that's equal parts hummus, tahini, and awesome), and crunchy fresh lettuce, tomatoes, onions, and what have you (the latter being a plant from the "StuffnThings" genus).  They also have super good pickled turnips.  Sound weird?  Eat it anyway, you'll like it.

One of the qualms I have is that Sunrise is not the best place to go if you're trying to eat healthily.  Since I almost always turn to Mediterranean fare when I'm looking to ingest something biologically helpful, its very existence seems a little oxymoronic to me.  Sure falafel is vegetarian, but if you're looking to eat veg and avoid the fried (yes, even lightly fried), your best bet is either to get a bunch of dips and pita (which is tasty, but doesn't really feel like a meal) or a veggie wrap (which is good but not the best, kind of deflating when you want a bit more of a selection).

All in all, I wouldn't swear off my other Mediterranean haunts, but when I want some mind-numbingly delicious falafel, pleasant service, and a phenomenally hobbit-hole-like dining experience, I go to Sunrise straight away.
author: Becca S.

description:
I was on my way to find banh mi on Market when the dude out front of Sunrise put a little plate in my face. A whole piece of falafel, a square of pita, and a little cup of tahini. Hell yeah I'll try it. 

The falafel was basically perfect and had clearly just been cooked. Crispy outside, soft inside but not mushy and not dry at all. I dipped it in the tahini until it was gone and ate the rest with the pita.

Impressed, I felt obliged to try this and find those banh mi another day. I ordered the super falafel, and it was really good. Forgot to ask for hot sauce, unfortunately. I'll get it next time, which there surely will be.

Best falafel I've had South of Market. My bar is Baladie, but its a bit of a hike these days.  I'd say this was pretty close if not on par, slightly smaller serving (the lavash sandwiches at Baladie are gigantic, which is a good thing but sometimes too much food).
author: josh r.

description: Eh, not bad. Lamb shawarma tastes more like beef than lamb. The falafel is ok - not authentic. Crunchy on the outside, soft on the inside. Too well done for me. I'd recommend Gyro King or Ayola for gyro/wraps in the area over this place.
author: Vitaliy L.

description:
I was looking forward to trying Sunrise Deli - I had seen it under construction for some time. I took a look at their menu, and found the one item that didn't have tahini sauce or hummus (the chicken kabab sandwich.) I don't like any type of sauce on my sandwiches - so it looked like the best option. I ordered it, and I double checked with the cashier - "does it have any sauce on it?" He said yes - (even though the menu says otherwise) so I asked to hold the sauce.

I got back to my office, and find the falafel drenched in sauce. So I went back, and very politely asked if I could have another sandwich without any sauce. The cashier seemed very upset, and gave me major attitude about bringing it back and asking.

So i finally got my replacement sandwich - tasting it - they make no attempt at mixing the contents. I took one bite of all lettuce, another of all onions, and another of all chicken. really bad preparation. the chicken is burned, and has no taste. Maybe this is because the cashier was so upset with me for bringing back my first sandwich? To top it off, it's small! I'm going to have to go buy another lunch.

Either way, I would never go there again, and wouldn't recommend it to anyone else.
author: Nicholas M.

description: No idea why there are about 10 fast food Mediterranean places within these few blocks but Sunrise Deli just opened here so we gave it a try.  We ordered the kefta plate and it was very good! (ground beef grilled into patties) The kefta was flavorful and our side orders hummus and the yogurt mint thing were excellent as well.  The plate comes with rice but also yummy pita bread and it was almost enough to share for 2 people.  Would definitely come here again.
author: Betty C.

description: Best falafel and pita chips in the neighborhood. I always have the falafel plate and it is amazing. I have had falafels at a few other places in the city, but nothing compares to the falafels they have at sunrise deli.
author: Anand G.

description:
So far I've only had the falafel here and i love it. 
Just the right amount of food and a fair price for the area.
author: Cameron C.

description: I ordered the veggie combo and also ordered the chocolate dessert w/ almonds and pistachio. Everything was pretty good. Wasn't too crowded on a Fri afternoon @ 2pm. Price and service are both ok.
author: Irene L.

description: Wow. the falafel here is quite good, homemade fresh and rivals Oasis.  I got the avacado falafel which is good.  One drawback is the pita bread which is thin.  I am going to try the Super Falafel next week to see if it's on par or better than the falafel wrap at Oasis.
author: Josh L.

description:
The people are very friendly. They offer sample while you wait (very customer service oriented)
The falafel is very very good. 
Humus is pretty good.
Pita Chips, they make this fresh daily, quite good.
Greek Salad; fresh but the chunks are too large, hard to eat.
I will be back to try more stuff.
author: Monica H.

description: Sunrise Deli will make you change your mind about any previous falafel experience.  My first experience with falafel was what I had expected: very grainy and dry.  My friend told me that Sunrise Deli was a must-try in the Bay Area, so I gave it a try. Falafel is now on one of my top foods list, but for now only that from SF/BAy Area.  Their falafel wraps (original, avocado and super) are the best on the menu.  It's so good; I probably go once a week for lunch.
author: Linda L.

description: Just had the falafel plate and it was delicious.  I'm always suspicious of proclamations such as "best falafel in town" but this falafel actually IS really tasty and more moist than many others.  This place has a busy lunch crowd and it's easy to see why.  A bit expensive at $9 for most of their lunch plates, but no more so than everywhere else downtown.
author: Molly P.

description:
What it lacks for in decor, it makes up for in taste! I had a super falafel sandwich today that was really yummy and well made. My dining companion had the special moussaka, which looked very good. Next time I go (and there will be a next time), I'll have to try something with meat! 

The restaurant could stand to spruce things up a bit, maybe play some music or something. It's nice to have an upstairs area, but be careful of the steps - they're made for tiny-footed people.
author: Marcus C.

description:
the falafels are pretty tasty.  crispy on the outside and flavorful on the inside.   i really enjoyed their "regular" falafel.  they also have a "super" falafel, but i decided to keep it simple.  

they serve the falafel in a pita and they cut it in half, wrapping both halfs SEPERATELY!!  they already won me over when i saw this.  did they know that i have portion control issues with my food?  thanks for looking out sunrise deli!!  

i also got the mujudara (lentils and rise) side.  it was okay, unfortunately i've had better.  

next time, its a falafel and i'm trying a side of the baba ganoush.
author: Brenda H.

description: The chicken in the wrap I ordered was pretty dry.  The sauce they used was pretty meh and the size of the wrap was pretty small.  I'm not saying it's the worst I ever had, but I don't think I would ever go back.
author: Francisco R.

description: The chicken kebab plate was not that great. You get to choose two sides with the chicken kebab. What made the plate not good was the chicken. The chicken was dry and lacked flavor. On the other hand, the veggie plate is tastier and is a better deal. The falafel is pretty good, one of the best I've had. The veggie plate is plentiful, so you definitely can have a hearty meal with a plate. Overall, I would probably not go again.
author: Vera W.

description: I have to say this is a solid lunch spot.  Lines are rarely long (we go earlier than 12).  Service is fast and you can get to go or sit down.  I've only had the vegetarian dishes so can't comment on the meat.  The falafel is awesome.  I either get the sandwich or the veggie combo.  This is a regular in the lunch rotation.
author: Sameer D.

description: Look, their falafel is delicious and their tabbouleh is a tasty treat, but man i wish their hummus wasn't so watery, and it tastes a bit too tahini-y. Same with the baba, making them both a bit chalky tasting. On prior visits, they warmed my pita but it was not to be this time. Sadness enveloped my being. I mean its the FiDi (shoot me for using that please), you can't expect too much on the 'its goodness motherfucker' scale. it'll do pig.
author: mike t.

description: Best falafel in town :)  It's moist, flavorful and fresh and I love the fact that it comes with potatoes and eggplant (if you get the super falafel, which is what I always get).  This falafel actually reminds me of the one I've had in Israel, sooo good! :)
author: Yanina K.

description: The best falafel I've had in a long time. Not at all dry, yet really nicely fried - their hot sauce is fantastic, and the humus, lettuce, pickled veggies, etc on top make it ideal. Will be going back a lot . . .
author: A. D.

description: The Falafels at this place are one word, AMAZING. I haven't had many around the city, but these are to die for. I usually get the Avocado Falafel, and it is filled with crispy, creamy, crunchy goodness. Today I ordered the Lentil Soup, because I wanted something less filling and warm on this freezing Winter day. Was I surprised that their soup was delicious as well? Nope, not really. Thank goodness this place is literally across the street. I need my Falafel fix at least once a week!
author: Trisha A.

description: I usually like this place a lot, and I would always end up full since they offer adequate portions. However, I went in today for lunch (which I ordered to go) and when I opened it up back in my office I noticed that the kufta kabab portions were half the size they usually are. There were even some charred bits around the edges. I was really dissapointed in how skimpy the meal was all around, as they definitely didn't provide enough tahini either. I might go back if I really have a craving for it, but this definitely made me hesitant and it's no longer in my top choices for lunch. Especially considering I paid $12 and some change. Plus, there's another good place nearby so I will most likely go there instead from now on.
author: Susie N.

description:
I had the chicken shawarma. I really liked it! How it tasted I mean....the not-so-good thing about it is you can't really eat it like a sandwich because it falls apart. So I ended up just cutting it open and eating it like a salad. My friend got a half-dozen falafels which were delicious but gave me heart burn since they were deep fried. 
Decor could use some help, but otherwise the food tastes good. I might come back to try something else, but this isn't the kind of place I'm dying to go back to.
author: Juju B.

description: very friendly people, but the falafel was tasteless and lousy. dang.
author: Dana D.

description: This place is awesome; I work across the street and come here all the time.  I usually order the falafel sandwich because it's cheap and it's a lot of food.  The sandwiches have four pieces of falafel that are cooked to order.  You can't go wrong at Sunrise Deli
author: Kevin K.

description: Better than I was expecting, for the area. Their falafel isn't mushy, hummus and Babgnoush, nicely zingy. Tabouleh, not overloaded with parsley. Well done, Sunrise Deli.
author: K S.

description: This place is the bomb-diggety. The deluxe falafel with eggplant = a happy mouth, a happy belly, and a happy you. When given the choice, always choose Sunrise over Ayola (just say no to extra grease and unnecessary costliness).
author: Lorelle M.

description: I ordered the chicken shawarma sandwich. The chicken was terrible - tiny chunks that were tough and almost inedible. Might have been tendons as opposed to actualy meat. The pita fell apart immediately.
author: James F.

description: all i have to say is that REAL hummus doesn't drip off..never thought you can water down hummus , but  apparently sunrise deli does..
author: Omar I.

description:
These folks are wonderful. They catered our office holiday party last December and everything was perfect.

They were incredibly accommodating all through the menu selection process, even letting us sample items. Calls were returned promptly, business was polite and professional, and never was I left wondering about anything. 

The food was delivered promptly by gentlemen who helped us haul it upstairs... and it was absolutely delicious, still warm, cleanly and professionally packaged. Many glowing comments were made about the food through the evening. 

I recommend these folks without reservation. Thanks again, Sunrise Deli!!!
author: K L.

description: Really great falafel, but expensive! There's seating downstairs and if you go up a steep bunch of steps, plenty of seating upstairs. As far as a downtown lunch place goes, it's fine. Definitely a good choice if you're hankering for falafel.
author: Grace Y.

description: I had a meeting in the City and stumbled upon this place right around lunch time. Their avocado falafel is my new favorite. Looking forward to my next meeting in the FD.
author: Stacy B.

description:
I had the basic falafel at $5.99.  Appeared to have fresh ingredients and not too much sauce.

The place is clean with what appears to be newer tables and chairs (July 2010) so instead of running back to the office, my two co-workers stayed and ate in the restaurant.
author: John C.

description: Yay! Love Sunrise on Irving, now I have it around the corner from work! Picked up the Vegetarian Combo for lunch - about $10 for tabouli, babghanuj, hummus, rice & lentils, tomato & cucumber salad, falafel, dolma, and pita - a little pricey, but it comes with a ton of food.  The falafel is just as delicious as at the Irving St location. yummmmm.
author: marissa a.

description: I often wander around when I'm at school looking for a new place to eat ,and on Tuesday I found this diamond in the rough.My kufta kebab platter was seasoned deliciously. Ample sides came with the meat,loved the tabouleh .Friendly staff.My only issue was the zoo like line nearly out the door. I will definitely be back
author: Lauren V.

description:
Everything was kind of bland, or just a little off. Hummus was a little sour. Tabboleh was soft, no texture. Falafel and eggplant in super falafel bland. A hot sauce option would be nice. 

Pickled turnips are great and always welcome. Chicken kabob was cooked to order, which was nice.

Given the prices (not crazy, but not cheap), I'd like something with a little more flavor.

Absolutely does not hold a candle to Truly Mediterranean

Also, given that they have a relatively small menu, and a relatively long line at lunch, they should really call out numbers. When the guy at the counter shouts "falafel sandwich to go" everyone kind of jumps up at once ;)
author: Wangston P.

description: Best falafel I have ever had!   It was crispy on the outside and not dry AT ALL.  The veggie plate was delicious and satisfying I am def a meat eater. I really like this place and will definitely go back. The only thing is that the prices seem just a bit high but not enough to stay away :0)
author: TJ E.

description: Good food in the FiDi that isn't a tiny salad. I'm all over it. The pita bread is a little thin though.
author: Alex M.

description: Sunrise Deli = Pure Bliss. I originally became a fan of their location on Irvine St. and I was pumped when I found out a new location was opening in the financial district just a few blocks from my workplace. The falafel plate at Sunrise is delectable and comes with 3 to 4 huge falafels and pita bread which you makes a great sandwich when you add in the tahini sauce and salad. The lamb shwarma and baklava are also highlights. If your craving a reasonably priced hearty meal, Sunrise Deli is sure to leave you satisfied and wanting to come back for more.
author: Husain K.

description: Came to Sunrise Deli for lunch on my 25th b-day.  Wanted to give this place a try since it's new to the neighborhood.  I got a lamb schwarma and split some dolmas with my buddy.  Overall very tasty.  The only thing that would've made the schwarma better would have been more tender meat and thinner slices.  At times you had to gnaw it off which was tough.  Definitely seems like they are getting good business.  I'd be willing to go back and try something else out--perhaps falafel?
author: Christopher W.

description: Sunrise is good for a quick and inexpensive lunch. They have pretty much all of the typical middle eastern type dishes. I had the falafel and the dolmas, both of which were good though I thought the dolmas could have been a little less tart. Regardless it's good food that won't break the bank.
author: Priyam D.

description:
I work around the corner, so I knew I'd have to try this place when it opened.  I got the avocado falafel sandwich on pita.  The falafel itself is fantastic: crisp on the outside, moist on the inside, nice and flavorful.

Construction was fine on my sandwich, no leakage here.  Pita was somewhat thin, but I wouldn't call it bland or stale in the least.  

Quick service, no complaints.

I think I might go for the deluxe on lavash next time.  I'll definitely be back.

Thanks guys!
author: John D.

description:
the best taboleh I have ever had!!!!

the hummus was good  too

the price was fair and we got as much pita as needed
author: Alaine L.

description: Just finished my chicken shawarma.  The pita I got was broken and all the chicken, lettuce, and sauce came running out.  The chicken was dry and definitely needed more of the yogurt sauce.  For 7.65 including tax, for a small portion, there's definitely more options in downtown for lunch.  Honestly I would prefer to go Oasis Grill for a chicken shawarma.  I'm pissed off of myself, I should of walked around the corner for D. Leary's corn beef sandwich instead.
author: Calvin H.

description: I was wandering around aimlessly today with a growling stomach and couldn't figure out what I wanted for lunch.   (Hate it when that happens!)  Then I saw a sign that said Sunrise Deli.  Hhmmmm, I thought to myself, could this be the SAME Sunrise Deli on Irving that has the best falafel in the world???  Hurray - it is!  I grabbed a regular falafel sandwich and "treated" myself to a piece of pistachio baklava (what the hell, it's the holidays).   The pita bread is nothing special but I'm happy to report that the falafel in this location is just as awesome!
author: Michelle E.

description: Food is delicious.  They handle the lunch rush with aplomb!  If you don't like the price, don't go out for lunch in the Financial District.
author: jaf D.

description: It may be because I got there when they opened, but damn, they had the best falafel I've ever tasted. Crispy and flavorful. Otherwise, everything else was on average of the usual Middle-Eastern foods, so nothing too much else to write home about. It's not too expensive considering SF either.
author: Tony T.

description: Sunrise rocks falafel, hummus, kefta kabob and moussaka. The food is excellent, homemade, fresh, and relatively cheap. The staff are prompt and friendly. Modest interior - it's not a sit-down joint to visit on a date. But for something to eat on your lunchbreak, it's one of my top favorites.
author: Andy H.

description: Lamb kebab plate has no taste of lamb. The ground meat has way too much herbs instead of meat. It is actually green inside vs color of meat.  Tastes nothing like in all other places and its overpriced for the serving size.  No Hot tea, which is a must in places like this.
author: Vitaliy V.

description: Took advantage of the Living Social Instant Deal ($6 for $10.) Chicken Kabab sandwich and pita chips. The chicken was well prepared, good flavor and the grilled onions in the sandwich were tasty. Price was reasonable. Overall I prefer Sunrise to some of the other Middle Eastern places in the area.
author: Joseph S.

description: Pretty delicious...great falafels... loved the chicken kabobs... oh man.. in a place of the FiDi/SoMa area where the food can be very mediocre and bland at expensive prices..... i was in shock! So the 5* is accomplishing good food at good prices in the specific neighborhood.
author: Jeannette L.

description: Not sure why people think this falafel is good.  I had the plate and the falafel was cold, and the hummus runny and watered down.  If you want good falafel, go to Truly Mediteranean on 16th off of Valencia.  It's always fresh, and delicious.  Puts this place to shame.
author: Sue S.

description: this place is amazing.  i ordered their veggie plate for a meeting.  the food was delicious and they had it ready on time.  it was supposed to be enough to feed 10-12 people.  15 people filled their plates at least once and we still had leftovers.  i will definately order from here again.
author: sofiya f.

description: I was so gosh darn excited to try this place after all the ranting and raving I heard about the other one. I ordered the lamb schwarma. The pita bread was bland and thin, not fluffy like a good pita. More like a store bought, slightly stale pita. The lettuce took up most of the sandwich, subsided by some small, bite size pieces of lamb, which to be frank, was not all that flavorful. The portions are pretty small, particularly for the price (mine came to $7.65 with tax for the sandwich, no drink). The one thing that saved this place is that they were giving away free falafal balls, which are clearly how this place got its reputation in the first place. The ball was good. If I end up returning that is what I will stick to.
author: Caedmon P.

description: For full disclosue, I'm not that big of a fan of Arabic food and so perhaps not the best judge but I've been going to the Sunrise Deli in the Sunset  for quite some time now because in my opinion they have some of the best takeout Arabic food in the Bay. Definitely their falafels are the freshest I've tasted and their chicken shawarma is outstanding. So when I saw that they were opening a new store less than 5 min from my work office I was estatic. Since they've opened I've been going there about twice a week and havent gotten tired of it yet. I'd recommend going from 1 to 2 pm because from 12 to 1 it's insanely busy. I've also taken my work collegues who seem to enjoy it as well (this location has a lot more seating than the other one). My colleagues like the lentil soup and some of the vegetarian stuff but I've never tried it so I cant really speak on it. For someone that usually spends almost $10-15 per lunch I find this place to be on the cheap side - which is another plus. A few times after eating I've purchased some pita bread, half-dozen falafels and a tub of hummus to take home and make sandwiches - a quick way to make dinner when I'm too lazy after work. Only down side so far is that they dont sell red bull.
author: Phil W.
